    What is 'The Story Hunt'?

    'The Story Hunt: Uncover the EU' is a programme hosted by Datenschule and OpenBudgets of Open Knowledge Foundation Germany. Together with journalists, domain-experts, developers and designers , we want to develop and practice the skills needed to hunt stories in financial data.

    The programme is split into two parts: a series of tutorials (The Bootcamp) and a weekend-long workshop (The Data Expedition) in a forgotten castle outside of Berlin. During this weekend, we are going to dive into a massive database on the European Unions primary financial instrument, the ESIFunds.

    Uncover the EU

    The EU and its money flows are notoriously complex and partially intransparent. Over the past year, the team behind SubsidyStories.eu has gathered, cleaned, and concatenated data on the EU’s most important financial instrument: the European Structural Investment Funds (ESIF). Together with representatives of different disciplines (journalists, developers, domain experts, and designers) we want to immerse ourselves in the this data, hunting for stories.

    That is why Open Knowledge Germany has worked over the past year to open data on EU subsidies with subsidystories.eu. This is only the beginning of our EU Transparency work and we would invite the participants to work with this data, and work together with us on topics in EU Transparency.

    Trainings

    The Bootcamp is a series of tutorials happening prior to the weekend-long story hunt. Depending on your skill level, it is highly recommended that you participate in order to develop the basic skillset needed to work on the data we are working with.

    The trainings offered cover the basic skills of finding, scraping, analysing, and visualising data. The Bootcamp will take place in the offices of OKF DE in Berlin.

    Join the bootcamp and become a full-fledged hunch-hunter!

    1. Getting Finished

    16 May 2017

    The first meeting will be an introduction in the coming weeks topics. We will present inspiring data journalism stories and give an introduction of large data projects at OKFDE such as subsidystories.eu and JedeSchule.de.

    Register Now!

    2. Finding and Getting the Data

    23 May 2017

    In this workshop we will start with the basics of data. We put questions to datasets and discuss effective ways to find data, how to get to know your data and spreadsheet tips and tricks.

    Register Now!

    3. Scraping Data

    30 May 2017

    In this workshop we explain the basics of scraping and show you meaningful ways and tools to obtain data from the web.

    Register Now!

    4. Cleaning Data

    6 June 2017

    In most cases, datasets are messy and need to be cleaned in some ways. Tools such as OpenRefine and Excel provide great ways to produce clean data.

    Register Now!

    5. Analytics: Basic Intro into Statistics & Spreadsheets

    13 June 2017

    Statistics have a bad reputation of being hard, and manipulative. In this workshop we will show why you should use statistics and how you can use basic statistics to validate your data, understand it and run basic functions for first analysis.

    Register Now!

    6. Visualising Data

    20 June 2017

    Data comes to life in visualisations. In this workshop we will discuss ground rules of design and data visualisations. We will work on telling a story with data.

    Register Now!

    Data Expedition

    A data expedition is a combination of group work, training, and mutual learning that teaches the whole investigative process from the first questions and hypotheses through data and analysis to stories, presentations and visualisations. It equips the participants with the skills that they need in the field to work on a data-driven story, and allows us to produce concrete results in one weekend.

    Forming mixed teams, the groups will go through the “data-pipeline” together starting by asking the question to presenting the data in the course of 3 days.

    Together with the teams of Datenschule and OpenBudgets.eu, we will host a data expedition. On this three day workshops, you will work together with 25 experts from the field of journalism, programming, EU, advocacy, and design to work on data, analysis and story-telling.

    In a data expedition group members take on different roles in the process depending on their expertise:

    Storyteller:

    Ask interesting questions, guide creation of final project

    Scout

    ask interesting questions, guide creation of final project

    Analyst:

    Ask interesting questions, guide creation of final project

    Engineer:

    Ask interesting questions, guide creation of final project

    Designer:

    Ask interesting questions, guide creation of final project

    Analyst: crunch the data, test hypotheses Engineer: build final project, handle technical tasks Designer: ensure final project is transparent and effective
